controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.ip_forward is configured
controls.description:
\

\f2\b0 The 
\f0 \cf4 net.ipv4.ip_forward
\f2 \cf2  flag tells the system whether it can forward IPv4 packets or\
not.\

\f1\b Note:\

\f0\b0\fs20\fsmilli10080 \'95
\f2  
\f1\b\fs24 If this system is a router this recommendation is not applicable.\

\f0\b0\fs20\fsmilli10080 \'95

\f0 \cf4 net.ipv4.conf.all.forwarding=0
\f2 \cf2  and\

\f0 \cf4 net.ipv4.conf.default.forwarding=0
\f2 \cf2  are configured, this recommendation\
may be skipped.\

\f1\b
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology\
information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system\
network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.\
Setting 
\f0 \cf4 net.ipv4.ip_forward
\f2 \cf2  to 
\f0 \cf4 0
\f2 \cf2  ensures that a system with multiple interfaces (for\
example, a hard proxy), will not be able to forward IPv4 packets.\

\f1\b
controls.impact:
\

\f2\b0 IP forwarding is required on systems configured to act as a router. If these parameters\
are disabled, the system will not be able to perform as a router.\

outside routing device to update your system routing tables.\

\f2 \cf2  controls accepting of all IPv4 ICMP\
redirected packets on all interfaces.\

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter is configured\
controls.description:
\

\f0\b0 \cf4 net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter
\f2 \cf2  controls reverse path filtering for IPv4 traffic on all\
network interfaces.\
Reverse path filtering is a security mechanism in Linux that helps prevent IP spoofing\
and other network attacks. When enabled, it checks if the source IP address of an\
incoming packet is reachable through the same network interface it was received on. If\
the packet's source address is not reachable through the interface it arrived on, the\
packet is dropped.\

\f
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 Setting 
\f0 \cf4 net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter
\f2 \cf2  to 
\f0 \cf4 1
\f2 \cf2  is a good way to deter attackers from\
sending your system bogus packets that cannot be responded to. One instance where\
this feature breaks down is if asymmetrical routing is employed. This would occur when\
using dynamic routing protocols (bgp, ospf, etc) on your system. If you are using\
asymmetrical routing on your system, you will not be able to enable this feature without\
breaking the routing.\

\f
controls.impact:
\

\f2\b0 If you are using asymmetrical routing on your system, you will not be able to enable this\
feature without breaking the routing.
\fs20\fsmilli10080 Page 495\

\f0 Internal Only - General\

\f2\b0 When 
\f0 \cf4 tcp_syncookies
\f2 \cf2  is set, the kernel will handle TCP SYN packets normally until\
the half-open connection queue is full, at which time, the SYN cookie functionality kicks\
in. SYN cookies work by not using the SYN queue at all. Instead, the kernel simply\
replies to the SYN with a SYN/ACK, but will include a specially crafted TCP sequence\
number that encodes the source and destination IP address and port number and the\
time the packet was sent. A legitimate conn
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 Attackers use SYN flood attacks to perform a denial of service attacked on a system by\
sending many SYN packets without completing the three way handshake. This will\
quickly use up slots in the kernel's half-open connection queue and prevent legitimate\
connections from succeeding. Setting 
\f0 \cf4 net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies
\f2 \cf2  to 
\f0 \cf4 1
\f2 \cf2  enables SYN\
cookies, allowing the system to keep accepting valid connections, even if under a denial\
of service attack.

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_ra is configured\
controls.description:
\

\f2\b0 Routers periodically Multicast Router Advertisement (RA) messages to announce their\
availability and convey information to neighboring nodes that enable them to be\
automatically configured on the network.\

\f0 \cf4 net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_ra
\f2 \cf2  controls accepting IPv6 RA messages on newly\
added network devices.\

\f1\b Note: If IPv6 has been disabled, this recommendation is not applicable.\
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 It is recommended that systems do not accept router advertisements as they could be\
tricked into routing traffic to compromised machines. Setting hard routes within the\
system (usually a single default route to a trusted router) protects the system from bad\
routes.
\fs20\fsmilli10080 Page 566\

\f0 Internal Only - General\
